description: Utility for managing and configuring IPMI-enabled devices (BMC) including power control, sensor monitoring, and system event logs. ipmitool provides a command-line interface to manage Baseboard Management Controllers (BMC) on servers, enabling out-of-band management for power operations, hardware monitoring, serial-over-LAN access, and event logging. It supports both local (in-band) and remote (out-of-band) IPMI access through various interfaces.

installation.notes: On RHEL/CentOS: yum install ipmitool. On Ubuntu/Debian: apt install ipmitool. Requires IPMI kernel modules (ipmi_devintf, ipmi_si) for local access. Remote access requires network connectivity to BMC and valid credentials.

global_options.description: Select IPMI interface to use. Available interfaces include: open (local OpenIPMI driver), lanplus (IPMI v2.0 RMCP+ encrypted), lan (IPMI v1.5), serial (direct serial port), and others.
Remote BMC host IP address or hostname. Required for remote IPMI operations.
Username for remote IPMI session authentication.
Remote session password. Note: Using -P on command line may expose password in process list. Consider using -f for password file or -E for environment variable.
Read password from file. More secure than command-line password.
Read password from IPMI_PASSWORD environment variable.
Remote IPMI RMCP port. Default is 623 (UDP).
Force session privilege level. Levels are: CALLBACK, USER, OPERATOR, ADMIN. Different operations require different privilege levels.
Increase verbose output level. Can be specified multiple times (-vvv) for more detail.
Display output in comma-separated format for easier parsing.
Cipher suite to use for lanplus interface. Common values: 3 (uses AES-128-CBC), 17 (AES-128-CBC with RAKP-HMAC-SHA256).
Bridge IPMI requests to a remote target address (for multi-node chassis).
Specify the channel number for bridged requests.

subcommands.name: power status
subcommands.description: Get the current power status of the system. Returns 'on' or 'off' indicating whether the host is powered on.

subcommands.name: power on
subcommands.description: Power on the system. Equivalent to pressing the power button when system is off.

subcommands.name: power off
subcommands.description: Power off the system immediately. Hard power off - does not gracefully shutdown OS.

subcommands.name: power cycle
subcommands.description: Power cycle the system. Performs a hard power off followed by power on after a brief delay.

subcommands.name: power reset
subcommands.description: Reset the system. Performs a hard reset without power cycling (warm reboot).

subcommands.name: power soft
subcommands.description: Initiate soft shutdown via ACPI. Signals the OS to perform graceful shutdown, similar to pressing power button briefly.

subcommands.name: sdr list
subcommands.description: List all Sensor Data Records (SDRs) with current readings. Shows all sensors known to the BMC including temperature, voltage, fan speed, and discrete sensors.

subcommands.name: sdr type
subcommands.description: List sensors of a specific type. Common types include Temperature, Voltage, Fan, Current, and various discrete sensor types.

subcommands.name: sdr info
subcommands.description: Display information about the SDR repository including version, record count, free space, and timestamps.

subcommands.name: sensor list
subcommands.description: List all sensors with current readings, states, thresholds, and units. Provides more detailed output than sdr list.

subcommands.name: sensor get
subcommands.description: Get detailed information about a specific sensor including current reading, thresholds, and event status.

subcommands.name: sensor thresh
subcommands.description: Set sensor thresholds. Can set upper and lower thresholds for warning (non-critical), critical, and non-recoverable levels.

subcommands.name: sel list
subcommands.description: List System Event Log (SEL) entries. Shows hardware events such as temperature excursions, power events, memory errors, and other critical system events.

subcommands.name: sel info
subcommands.description: Display SEL information including version, entries count, free space, and timestamps.

subcommands.name: sel clear
subcommands.description: Clear the System Event Log. Use with caution as this permanently removes all logged events.

subcommands.name: sel time get
subcommands.description: Get the current BMC time used for SEL timestamps.

subcommands.name: sel time set
subcommands.description: Set the BMC time for SEL timestamps. Time should be in format: MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS

subcommands.name: sel elist
subcommands.description: List SEL entries with extended sensor descriptions for more readable output.

subcommands.name: chassis status
subcommands.description: Display chassis status including power state, power restore policy, last power event, chassis intrusion, and front panel buttons status.

subcommands.name: chassis identify
subcommands.description: Control the chassis identify LED. Used to physically locate a server in a datacenter. Default is 15 seconds if no interval specified.

options.description: Number of seconds to blink identify LED. Use 0 for off, or 'force' for indefinite.

subcommands.name: chassis bootdev
subcommands.description: Set the next boot device for the system. Options include pxe, disk, cdrom, bios, and safe.

options.description: Boot from default hard disk in safe mode

subcommands.name: chassis bootparam
subcommands.description: Get or set boot parameters for more advanced boot configuration.

subcommands.name: chassis power
subcommands.description: Alias for power command. Controls system power state.

subcommands.name: lan print
subcommands.description: Print LAN channel configuration including IP address, MAC address, subnet mask, gateway, and other network settings.

subcommands.name: lan set
subcommands.description: Configure LAN channel settings. Allows setting IP address, netmask, gateway, VLAN, and various authentication parameters.

subcommands.name: fru print
subcommands.description: Print Field Replaceable Unit (FRU) information including product name, manufacturer, serial number, and other asset data.

subcommands.name: fru list
subcommands.description: List all FRU devices in the system.

subcommands.name: fru read
subcommands.description: Read FRU data to a file.

subcommands.name: fru write
subcommands.description: Write FRU data from a file.

subcommands.name: mc info
subcommands.description: Display Management Controller (BMC) information including device ID, firmware revision, IPMI version, manufacturer, and product ID.

subcommands.name: mc reset cold
subcommands.description: Perform a cold reset of the BMC. This fully resets the BMC and may temporarily interrupt IPMI connectivity.

subcommands.name: mc reset warm
subcommands.description: Perform a warm reset of the BMC. Less disruptive than cold reset but may not clear all BMC state.

subcommands.name: mc guid
subcommands.description: Display the BMC globally unique identifier (GUID).

subcommands.name: mc watchdog get
subcommands.description: Get current watchdog timer settings and status.

subcommands.name: mc watchdog reset
subcommands.description: Reset the watchdog timer countdown.

subcommands.name: mc watchdog off
subcommands.description: Disable the watchdog timer.

subcommands.name: user list
subcommands.description: List IPMI users configured on the BMC for a specific channel.

subcommands.name: user set name
subcommands.description: Set the username for a user ID.

subcommands.name: user set password
subcommands.description: Set the password for a user ID.

subcommands.name: user enable
subcommands.description: Enable a user account.

subcommands.name: user disable
subcommands.description: Disable a user account.

subcommands.name: user priv
subcommands.description: Set user privilege level.

subcommands.name: sol activate
subcommands.description: Activate Serial-over-LAN (SOL) session to access system console remotely.

subcommands.name: sol deactivate
subcommands.description: Deactivate an active SOL session.

subcommands.name: sol info
subcommands.description: Display SOL configuration and status.

subcommands.name: sol set
subcommands.description: Configure SOL parameters.

subcommands.name: channel info
subcommands.description: Display information about an IPMI channel.

subcommands.name: channel getaccess
subcommands.description: Get user access settings for a channel.

subcommands.name: channel setaccess
subcommands.description: Set user access settings for a channel.

subcommands.name: raw
subcommands.description: Send a raw IPMI command. Used for advanced operations not covered by other subcommands.

subcommands.name: bmc info
subcommands.description: Alias for 'mc info'. Display BMC information.

subcommands.name: bmc reset
subcommands.description: Alias for 'mc reset'. Reset the BMC.

output_formats.default: Human-readable format with labeled fields and values. Sensor readings include units and status.
output_formats.csv: Comma-separated values format enabled with -c flag. Useful for scripting and parsing.
output_formats.verbose: Detailed output with additional diagnostic information, enabled with -v flag.

environment_variables.name: IPMI_PASSWORD
environment_variables.description: Password for IPMI session authentication when using -E flag.
environment_variables.affects_command: Provides password for remote IPMI sessions without exposing it on command line.

environment_variables.name: IPMITOOL_DEBUG
environment_variables.affects_command: Produces verbose diagnostic output for troubleshooting.

exit_codes.meaning: Error - command failed or returned an error

common_usage_patterns.description: List all sensor data records (local system)
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
CPU1 Temp        | 45 degrees C      | ok
CPU2 Temp        | 43 degrees C      | ok
Sys Fan 1        | 5400 RPM          | ok
PSU1 Status      | 0x01              | ok

common_usage_patterns.description: Check power status of remote server
common_usage_patterns.command: ipmitool -I lanplus -H 10.0.0.1 -U admin -P password power status

common_usage_patterns.description: List all sensors with detailed readings

common_usage_patterns.command: ipmitool -I lanplus -H 10.0.0.1 -U admin -P password chassis power cycle

common_usage_patterns.output_example:
1 | 01/15/2024 | 10:30:15 | Temperature #0x01 | Upper Critical going high | Asserted
   2 | 01/15/2024 | 10:31:20 | Temperature #0x01 | Upper Critical going high | Deasserted

CPU1 Temp        | 01h | ok  |  3.1 | 45 degrees C
CPU2 Temp        | 02h | ok  |  3.2 | 43 degrees C
Inlet Temp       | 03h | ok  |  7.1 | 22 degrees C
Exhaust Temp     | 04h | ok  |  7.2 | 35 degrees C

Device ID                 : 32
Device Revision           : 1
Firmware Revision         : 2.50
IPMI Version              : 2.0
Manufacturer ID           : 10876
Product ID                : 256

common_usage_patterns.description: Set next boot device to PXE
common_usage_patterns.command: ipmitool -I lanplus -H 10.0.0.1 -U admin -P password chassis bootdev pxe

common_usage_patterns.output_example:
Set in Progress         : Set Complete
Auth Type Support       : NONE MD5 PASSWORD
IP Address Source       : Static Address
IP Address              : 10.0.0.100
Subnet Mask             : 255.255.255.0
MAC Address             : 00:25:90:ab:cd:ef

common_usage_patterns.description: Identify server by blinking LED for 30 seconds

common_usage_patterns.output_example: Clearing SEL.  Please allow a few seconds to erase.

ID  Name             Callin  Link Auth  IPMI Msg   Channel Priv Limit
1   admin            true    false      true       ADMINISTRATOR
2   operator         true    false      true       OPERATOR

error_messages.message: Could not open device at /dev/ipmi0 or /dev/ipmi/0 or /dev/ipmidev/0
error_messages.meaning: IPMI device driver not loaded or not accessible
error_messages.resolution: Load IPMI kernel modules: 'modprobe ipmi_devintf' and 'modprobe ipmi_si'. Verify with 'lsmod | grep ipmi'. May require enabling IPMI in BIOS.

error_messages.message: Error: Unable to establish IPMI v2 / RMCP+ session
error_messages.meaning: Cannot connect to remote BMC via lanplus interface
error_messages.resolution: Verify BMC IP address is reachable, credentials are correct, and IPMI-over-LAN is enabled. Check firewall rules for UDP port 623.
Verify username and password are correct. Check that the user has appropriate privilege level for the operation.

error_messages.meaning: User does not have permission for the requested operation
error_messages.resolution: Use -L ADMIN flag if operation requires administrator privileges. Verify user privilege configuration with 'user priv' command.

error_messages.meaning: BMC firmware issue or communication problem
error_messages.resolution: Try again with increased timeout. Consider resetting BMC with 'mc reset cold' if accessible. May indicate BMC firmware bug.

error_messages.message: Error in open session response message: no matching cipher suite
error_messages.meaning: Cipher suite mismatch between client and BMC
error_messages.resolution: Try specifying a different cipher suite with -C flag. Common values are 3 (default) or 17. Check BMC cipher suite configuration.

error_messages.message: Unable to get Sensor Data Record
error_messages.resolution: BMC may be busy or SEL/SDR repository corrupted. Try again, or reset BMC if problem persists.
Password may be incorrect or contains special characters. Try with simpler password or use password file (-f) instead.

interoperability.notes: ipmitool is the most widely used IPMI management tool. FreeIPMI provides similar functionality with slightly different syntax. For large-scale deployments, consider tools like ipmiutil or vendor-specific management platforms. BMC sensor readings should generally correlate with OS-level sensors from lm-sensors.

permissions.read_operations: Local IPMI access typically requires root or membership in 'ipmi' group. Access to /dev/ipmi0 device is required. Remote operations require valid BMC credentials.
permissions.write_operations: All write operations (power control, configuration changes, BMC reset) require appropriate IPMI privilege level (OPERATOR or ADMIN). Local access requires root.
permissions.notes: Some systems allow non-root users to access IPMI through device permissions or sudo configuration. Remote access security depends on network isolation and strong credentials.

limitations: Password on command line may be visible in process listings - use -f or -E for security
IPMI v1.5 (lan interface) sends authentication in clear text - use lanplus for encryption
BMC firmware bugs may cause inconsistent behavior across different vendors
Sensor thresholds are BMC-dependent and may not match OS-reported values exactly
SOL (Serial-over-LAN) performance depends on network conditions and BMC implementation
Some operations may require vendor-specific extensions not covered by standard IPMI
Rate limiting by BMC may affect bulk operations on sensor or SEL queries
Maximum SEL size is limited; old events are lost when full unless cleared

reads_from.description: Reads hardware sensor data from BMC including temperature, voltage, fan speed, and power metrics. Also reads system event logs for hardware events.
Reads power state and boot configuration from BMC/chassis management interface.

writes_to.description: Controls system power (on/off/cycle/reset), sets boot device, and controls identify LED for physical server location.
Modifies BMC configuration including network settings, user accounts, clears SEL, and sets sensor thresholds.

triggered_by.effect: SEL event logged, sensor reading reflects current temperature
SEL event logged, PSU sensor status updated
SEL event logged, fan sensor shows warning or critical status
SEL event logged, intrusion sensor asserted
Power status command reflects new state, SEL may log event
SEL event logged with error details

consistent_with.shared_state: Temperature readings should generally correlate between IPMI and lm-sensors, though values may differ slightly due to different sensor locations and sampling
GPU temperature from nvidia-smi should correlate with ambient/inlet temperatures from IPMI sensors in typical thermal relationship
FreeIPMI tools (ipmi-sensors, ipmi-sel, etc.) read same BMC data as ipmitool
DCGM health checks may reflect conditions also visible in IPMI sensors (thermal, power)
